item.description:
"And in its forthright dealing with the play, this becomes one of the most scathingly honest American films ever made." -- Stanley Kauffmann, New York Times

This 1966 film is based on the Albee play of the same name. It boasts an impressive cast list (Elizabeth Taylor, Richard Burton) and marks Mike Nichols' directorial debut. The film has a Rotten Tomatoes rating of 96%, with only 1 bad review out of 27. The film is also #67 on the American Film Institute's list of the Top 100 American Films ever made and garnered 5 academy awards. According to Rotten Tomatoes, the film has a noir-ish feel and helped establish Nichols' reputation for delivering "intelligent, 'adult' films." It is also believed that Ernest Lehman's screenplay stayed true to the play's original script.

Plot synopsis from Rotten Tomatoes: "Mike Nichols' auspicious debut feature is a harrowing descent into the private lives and painful secrets of two couples thrown together for an evening."

This will be the groups first time seeing a film at the North End Public Library, which is a short walk from the Haymarket stop on the Green and Orange lines. I know nothing of the library's set-up for showing films, so this will be a test run of sorts. Luckily, the screening is free.

Afterwards, I was thinking we could head off to a North End cafe for food and discussion.
item.how_to_find_us: I will be holding a meetup sign after the movie is over.
item.name: Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf at North End Library
